ca.uqac.lif.cep

Class SingleProcessor

  • java.lang.Object
    • ca.uqac.lif.cep.Processor
      • ca.uqac.lif.cep.SingleProcessor
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Accumulator, BinaryProcessor, Caller, Combiner, Constant, Constant, CountDecimate, CountDecimate, Delay, Delay, Demultiplexer, EmlNumber, Filter, Filter, Fork, Freeze, Freeze, Function, GnuplotProcessor, Incrementer, Limiter, Passthrough, Passthrough, RegexTupleBuilder, Select, Sink, Sink, Source, Source, Threshold, TimeDecimate, TimeDecimate, TokenFeeder, Tuple, UnaryProcessor, Where, Window, Window, WindowProcessor

    public abstract class SingleProcessor
extends Processor
    Performs a computation on input events to produce output events.

    This is the direct descendant of Processor, and probably the one you'll want to inherit from when creating your own processors. While Processor takes care of input and output queues, SingleProcessor also implements Pullables and Pushables. These take care of collecting input events, waiting until one new event is received from all input traces before triggering the computation, pulling and buffering events from all outputs when either of the Pullables is being called, etc.

    The only thing that is left undefined is what to do when new input events have been received from all input traces. This is the task of abstract method compute(Object[]), which descendants of this class must implement.

    Author:
    Sylvain HallÃ©

    • Method Detail

      • reset

        public void reset()
        Description copied from class: Processor
        Resets the processor. This has for effect of flushing the contents of all input and output event queues. If the processor has an internal state, this should also reset this state to its "initial" settings (whatever that means in your context).
        Specified by:
        reset in class Processor

      • getPushableInput

        public final Pushable getPushableInput(int index)
        Description copied from class: Processor
        Returns the Pushable corresponding to the processor's i-th input trace.
        Specified by:
        getPushableInput in class Processor
        Parameters:
        index - The index. Should be between 0 and the processor's input arity - 1 (since indices start at 0).
        Returns:
        The pushable if the index is within the appropriate range, null otherwise.

        Parameters:

      • compute

        protected abstract Queue<Object[]> compute(Object[] inputs)
        Computes one or more output events from its input events
        Parameters:
        inputs - An array of input events; its length corresponds to the processor's input arity
        Returns:
        A queue of vectors of output events, or null if no event could be produced

      • wrapVector

        protected static final Queue<Object[]> wrapVector(Object[] v)
        Puts an array of objects (given as an argument) into an empty queue of arrays of objects. This is a convenience method that descendants of SingleProcessor (which implement compute(Object[])) can use to avoid a few lines of code when they output a single array of events.
        Parameters:
        v - The array of objects
        Returns:
        The queue, or null if all elements of v are null

      • wrapObject

        protected static final Queue<Object[]> wrapObject(Object o)
        Puts a object (given as an argument) into an empty queue of arrays of objects. This is a convenience method that descendants of SingleProcessor (which implement compute(Object[])) can use to avoid a few lines of code when they output a single event.
        Parameters:
        o - The object
        Returns:
        The queue
